repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
# TLDR

This PR enables the use of `hunspell`.

If you want to help:
- Try this PR _in your language_
- Report any error (they are probably caused by encoding problems).

# Mandatory motivation / problem disclaimer

Spellchecking in vim is notoriously bad at handling anything but english.
Furthermore, spelling suggestions are known to take a very long time to run (acknowledged in the docs).

Note though that it does not integrate within system dictionnaries by default (hunspell as a library does not enable that), but can use legacy vim spell files (the `.dic` and `.aff` files, but not the `.spl` ones that are specific to vim).

# Why hunspell ?

`hunspell` seems to be the most mature spellchecking project. It is supported on every single platform we can think of, and provides UTF-8 handling by default.

`hunspell` seems easier to include in our codebase, as it uses iconv, which we already include in out codebase.

In terms of performances, hunspell seems equivalent to vimspell when checking, and much faster when suggesting.

Other alternatives:
- `enchant`: requires `GLib`
- `nuspell`: misses some things like `SpellRare` support, requires `ICU`.

# Status
- Hunspell itself and dictionnaries
  - [x] Add `*.add` dictionnaries at runtime
  - [ ] `spellfile` (a bit tricky, might require manual parsing of the file...)
  - [ ] Add `spellpath` option for the list of paths to search for dictionnaries
- Spellchecking functions
  - [x] `spellsuggest()`
  - [x] `spellbadword()`
  - [x] `vim.spell.check()`
- Spell mappings
  - [x] `z=`
  - [x] `zg`
  - [x] `]s` `[s`
  - [x] `zG`
  - [ ] `zw`
  - [x] `zW`
- Spell commands
  - [x] `spellgood`
  - [x] `spellundo`
  - [x] `spellinfo`
  - [ ] `spellbad`
  - [ ] others
- Misc.:
  - [x] `<C-X><C-S>`

Things that are removed because handled by hunspell:
- Suggestion options:
  - `spellsuggest=double`
- Sound-folding in general (and `soundfold()`)
- `:mkspell`

Other marginal improvements:
- The internal wordlist is now stored in memory, instead of on-disk

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,25 @@
+#ifndef __HUNSPELL_WRAPPER_H__
+#define __HUNSPELL_WRAPPER_H__
+
+#include <hunspell/hunspell.h>
+#include <stdbool.h>
+#include <stdlib.h>
+
+#define HSPELL_COMPOUND (1 << 0)
+#define HSPELL_FORBIDDEN (1 << 1)
+#define HSPELL_ALLCAP (1 << 2)
+#define HSPELL_NOCAP (1 << 3)
+#define HSPELL_INITCAP (1 << 4)
+#define HSPELL_ORIGCAP (1 << 5)
+#define HSPELL_WARN (1 << 6)
+
+typedef struct hunspell_S hunspell_T;
+
+hunspell_T * hunspell_create(const char *affpath, const char *dicpath);
+
+void hunspell_destroy(hunspell_T *pHunspell);
+
+bool hunspell_is_wordchar(hunspell_T *handle, const char *p);
+
+bool hunspell_spell_flags(hunspell_T *handle, const char *p, size_t len, int *flags);

comment_data.body: and similarly for the other copypasta below ;)

Double underscores are reserved, it's best to avoid them
```suggestion
#ifndef HUNSPELL_WRAPPER_H
#define HUNSPELL_WRAPPER_H
```
Don't forget we also have `vim.spell.check` which avoids the viml bridge.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+vim.o.spelloptions = "hunspell"
+vim.o.spelllang = "en"
+vim.o.spell = true
+
+local total_time = os.time()
+local ITERATIONS = 1
+
+local errors = 0
+for i = 1, ITERATIONS do
+  local file = io.open("words", "r")
+  if not file then
+    error "Could not open wordlist"
+  end
+
+  errors = 0
+  for line in function() return file:read "*l" end do
+    local bad, suggs_plain = unpack(vim.split(line, "\t", { plain = true }))
+    print(bad)
+
+    local suggs = vim.split(suggs_plain, ', ', { plain = true, trimempty = true })
+
+    local bad_spell = vim.fn.spellbadword(bad)[1]

comment_data.body: Oh I forgot about that, I'll try it this way then.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+vim.o.spelloptions = "hunspell"
+vim.o.spelllang = "en"
+vim.o.spell = true
+

+

+    print(bad)

+
+    local bad_spell = vim.fn.spellbadword(bad)[1]

comment_regular_data.body:
If you don't bundle hunspell (which is OK for an optional feature), you need to add it to the build image here:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/22a88c425e2fe99bcb534e43396a0b00044ae67d/.github/workflows/ci.yml#L36
Will do :+1:

So I think this is pretty much working (but with some really rough edges).

I'll now work on integrating better all this, like correctly handle the changes of `spelloptions` to clear the language list and such.

Updated benchmark timings for `spell.check` (this is the time taken to spellcheck the whole list of ~4000 words):
vimSpell: ~`4` ms / 5 errors
hunspell: ~`9` ms / 3 errors

These two use the same dictionnaries, so I expect that the number of errors originates from the fact that they do not parse the dictionnary files the same way.

Timings differ a lot from benchmarks done before because I now exactly measure the sime to spellcheck (not the time to parse the file and such).

And the _real_ test will be suggestions anyway, especially for morphologically complex languages like French and German -- here vimSpell is notoriously bad, to the point where people often want to cancel out, if only they could...

> * Hunspell has significantly better and well-maintained dictionaries compared to vim spell.
> 
> * Nvim automatically pulls dictionaries somehow (similar to the old vim dictionaries).
>   
>   * We could host them in [neovim/deps](https://github.com/neovim/deps) perhaps.

Vim's spellfiles are essentially unmaintained.  That, to me, is the big win of using an external spell library.  Offload the maintenance (including distribution of the dictionaries) to the developers of the spell library.

It has nothing to do with "use the same saved words in all of my applications", but if that happens to be part of the end result, even better.

> Vim's spellfiles are essentially unmaintained. That, to me, is the big win of using an external spell library. Offload the maintenance (including distribution of the dictionaries) to the developers of the spell library.
> 
> It has nothing to do with "use the same saved words in all of my applications", but if that happens to be part of the end result, even better.

Also, having just one user spell dictionary for whole system, so I dont have to put same words to two different user dictionaries, is a plus.

I added a disclaimer in the description of the PR.


> * ballot_box_with_check  Eliminate the inlined c++ code. We shouldn't depend on a c++ compiler (for non-bundled deps), that is a new dependency.
>   
>   * Link to hunspell from system (or bundled) libs.
>   * Make hunspell a required dep. "Optional build-time features" are a complication that we have avoided for a very long time (except for very limited cases).
>   * Specify that we choose the LGPL license of hunspell.

I'll develop more about this when answering to the last point, but using the C interface to hunspell would prevent us from getting more detailed informations out of it.

I'll look into this and see what I can do anyway.

> * white_check_mark  Hunspell has significantly better and well-maintained dictionaries compared to vim spell.
> * ballot_box_with_check  Users on all platforms have a way to install dictionaries (compare how currently Nvim auto-downloads spellfiles).
>   
>   * We could host them in https://github.com/neovim/deps perhaps.

These three point are valid and I don't see if it blocks adoptance of hunspell in any way.

> * ballot_box_with_check **Remove support for the old vim spellfiles**.
>   
>   * Accept the limitations of hunspell and remove features that hunspell can't support.
>   * This allows us to focus on one paradigm, to keep maintenance burden manageable.

This is the interesting bit. When discussing about integrating hunspell, it was said that we should keep backward compatibility.

Not keeping support for legacy vim spellfiles would greatly simplify the code, and would maybe allow a deeper rework of the whole spellchecking codebase.

The amount of work would quite probably be more significant, but as your said, it would quite probably lower the maintenance burden a lot.

This point also has to be put in perspective with the first (C++ dependency). We could use the C-only API for hunspell, but writing our own wrapper for C++ APIs seems better as the C APIs are not really ideal (as an example, spellchecking in C++ allows to get details about the word being spellchecked, while that's not possible in C).

While I get that this is a problem with regard to the amount of dependency this PR adds, I this that the overrall advantages are numerous:
- Better performances
- Better language support
- Outsourcing dictionnaries / codebase management
- Lowering the development barrier of entry with regard to spell features.

> This is the interesting bit. When discussing about integrating hunspell, it was said that we should keep backward compatibility.

Unless hunspell is missing major features of vimspell, I think we need to just pick one. If we start maintaining a hunspell interface, we're in the hunspell business and we are no longer gaining much from supporting vimspell. At that point, vimspell is just a burden. We need to pick one and commit to it.

This is a user interface--scripts don't depend on vimspell. We would still have the same spell-related mappings and functions.

Other than vim patches, I don't think vimspell has required any real maintenance in years (if ever).

There needs to be some overlap of both existing for compat and user migration before we can consider choosing only one.

> Other than vim patches, I don't think vimspell has required any real maintenance in years (if ever).

1. We've had several non-trivial spell bugs/crashes that took time to fix (and sat on the issue tracker for a long time).
2. With two subsystems, vim patches will become more costly, because both must constantly be reconciled with the other. There is no reason to do so if hunspell has most of vimspell's features. If hunspell is missing a killer feature, then we don't want hunspell. Make a choice.

> There needs to be some overlap of both existing for compat and user migration before we can consider choosing only one.

What is a concrete example? I expect the same family of spell-related functions will mostly work, as well as mappings. So I don't understand where "migration" is needed.

> That will change if we have two subsystems, because both must constantly be reconciled with the other.

If vimspell isn't being actively developed, then I whole heartedly disagree this will introduce any additional burden. If it does actually introduce burden that we aren't happy with then we can make the decision to remove it then, as opposed to speculating.

> What is a concrete example? I expect the same family of spell-related functions will mostly work, as well as mappings. So I don't understand where "migration" is needed.

Fair. I guess if hunspell works similarly enough then this won't be a problem. We just don't know that yet, so having a workaround to offer users is preferable, especially while we work out the finer details, and especially since the perceived cost (from my POV) is quite low.

Bram spent a long time tuning and optimizing vimspell for English, so I wouldn't be surprised if it is actually better for English. I would definitely like to find out first.

(drive by comment but I wanted to answer some points)

Mainly regarding optimization and vim spell for english: the fun part is that vim spell is both worse and slower (for the suggestion part) than hunspell.

Bram himself admitted it: the code he wrote back then was to work around the lack of good libraries, but now they are probably okay.

There are a couple of good points that come with hunspell integration:
- drop-in dictionaries, maintained elsewhere
- actual support for non-English languages (I am speaking of features like compound words)
- better performances
- no weird compilation overhead for spell files
- (maybe) no need to download spell files from some FTP server: we could allow setting a search path for dictionnaries so that packagers allow to use the system dictionaries

> Other than vim patches, I don't think vimspell has required any real maintenance in years (if ever).

I am not sure whether the word required is the best word to use. The truth is also that `spell.c` is the longest and most complicated file in the vim codebase and so nobody has dared to touch it.

> If vimspell isn't being actively developed, then I whole heartedly disagree this will introduce any additional burden. If it does actually introduce burden that we aren't happy with then we can make the decision to remove it then, as opposed to speculating.

As usual, there is at least an interface burden. This means documentation would be more complicated, not to mention internals. Avoiding a decision here is a cop-out. A key goal of Neovim is to eliminate this kind of thing.

In that case doesn't the exact same principle apply to treesitter?

And I'm not saying to "avoid" the decision, I'm saying to "delay" it once we know the new thing IS better than the old thing.

> As usual, there is at least an interface burden. This means documentation would be more complicated, not to mention internals. Avoiding a decision here is a cop-out. A key goal of Neovim is to eliminate this kind of thing.

I think that both for tree-sitter and this could be temporary solution until tree-sitter and external-spellchecker are mature enough to be the only implementation.

> In that case doesn't the exact same principle apply to treesitter?

In principle yes, in practice no. The legacy of syntax is 1000x heavier than that of vimspell.

> And I'm not saying to "avoid" the decision, I'm saying to "delay" it once we know the new thing IS better than the old thing.

If hunspell turns out to be a mistake we can revert. Should be able to discover that before the next major release. And in that case I do not think we should support hunspell at all. Avoid kitchen-sink.

> If hunspell turns out to be a mistake we can revert. Should be able to discover that before the next major release. And in that case I do not think we should support hunspell at all. Avoid kitchen-sink.

I think that even more important than switch particularly to hunspell is to untangle spelling in neovim to clean API, which then can be served by another external spellchecker. E.g., I have heard some rumours about https://nuspell.github.io/ (and there are of course system spellcheckers in Mac OS X and Windows), so the spellchecking engine which will be used is not so important as the creation of API for communication with the external library.

If we are willing to convert the existing spellchecking code to another platform, it may be worth considering nuspell though.

Opening the door to another spellchecking library is nice, and maybe supporting a recent tool (like nuspell, which might bring some performance benefits even more than hunspell) might be a better long-term decision.

> If we are willing to convert the existing spellchecking code to another platform, it may be worth considering nuspell though.

Well, so far I see on Linux platforms hunspell as the default system spellchecker (used by, among others, LibreOffice, Thunderbird, Chromium, and Firefox), but yes nuspell can use hunspell dictionaries, so it is not that important.

Looking a little deeper into this, nuspell lacks some interesting features like helpers for tokenization of words, and finer-grained reports on the found word. 

I think hunspell is the safest bet here.

Following discussion on matrix: this PR will shift its goal to __remove legacy vim spell__.
It will take a little more time than expected, but I expect the results to be much better.
_UPDATE_: This PR now ships a default `en` dictionnary. One can thus test it with this dictionnary already.

So, how safe this is to use? I had this PR in my build just to check whether it is buildable, but when vimspell is going to be removed, will it actually break my spellchecker? (And no, I dont ask for 100% quality, just whether I get anything from my spellchecker now)

What's the purpose of the new top-level dir `nvim_hunspell/` ? I would think those files should live in runtime/ somewhere. Perhaps `spell2/` could be where we look for hunspell dictionaries, but more likely we just need a recognizable filename extension: `spell/en.utf-8.hunspell` or whatever (hopefully hunspell already has a standard extension).

Reminder: This is a draft PR for following along with the experimentation, not a PR ready to merge!

(`nvim_hunspell` contains test scripts for benchmarking etc. and is not part of the actual code. The actual dictionaries are in `runtime/spell`.)

> more likely we just need a recognizable filename extension: `spell/en.utf-8.hunspell` or whatever (hopefully hunspell already has a standard extension).

This is already the case as of this implementation:
- Vim only recognizes filenames like `{lang}.{encoding}.dic`
- This implementation finds names like `{lang}.dic`

_PROPOSAL_: It could be nice that our `spellfile` format changes (maybe also allowing arbitrary names that do not collide with `.add` which are meant to be dictionnaries extensions), se that it maps the `man 5 hunspell` "Personal dictionary file" format.

Otherwise, we could just ditch the loading of `.add` files (which is the remaining of the autoloading of `.add.spl` files), and use only those specified in `spellfile`.

In any case, I think that `spellfile`, as a user-facing extension mechanism, should use a similar (if not _the same_) format than the one in hunspell.

> Unless hunspell is missing major features of vimspell, I think we need to just pick one. 

For English and Dutch at least I found that Vim's spell checking is consistently much better than hunspell. I regularly have to copy/paste words from Firefox (which uses hunspell) to Vim to get any meaningful suggestions at all, and the ordering is usually much better in Vim.

I believe aspell is often better than hunspell for English too. Not the entire world is English of course and no doubt the situation is different for other languages, but English is obviously a major use case.

---

I wonder if something like a `spellfunc` option might be a better path forward for integrating hunspell or other tools; you can then write a function to parse the hunspell CLI:

    % hunspell -d en_US <<<helo
    Hunspell 1.7.0
    & helo 11 0: hole, help, helot, hello, halo, hero, hell, held, helm, he lo, he-lo

Or to check an entire file:

    % hunspell -d en_US -a [file]

Should also be much easier to implement, although need to think about how to best implement :spellgood, :spellbad, etc.

This way you could even have a `vimspell` CLI, set the best spell check tool for the language you're currently using, etc.

> In any case, I think that `spellfile`, as a user-facing extension mechanism, should use a similar (if not _the same_) format than the one in hunspell.

If we are using hunspell then the dict format should be the identical hunspell dict format. Otherwise we have to convert things, which leads to stale files, as seen with vimspell itself. It also adds a user burden (extra steps), complicates documentation, etc.

> something like a spellfunc option might be a better path forward ... then write a function to parse the hunspell CLI ... Should also be much easier to implement, although need to think about :spellgood, :spellbad, etc.

@arp242 Thanks for your feedback. The dealbreaker that led to deciding against 'spellfunc' is performance. If you want to try out this PR (or wait until it reaches mainline), comparing the results for English/Dutch will be valuable.

> The dealbreaker that led to deciding against 'spellfunc' is performance.

I haven't looked at it in detail (and I couldn't find any discussion it on the issue tracker), but `hunspell -l` on a 4,800 word document is ~70ms on my six-year old not-fast-at-all laptop, and `hunspell -d en_US <<<decompilation` to actually get the suggestions is ~5ms. A 83,594 word document is ~500ms though, which is a tad slow.

There is some added overhead from parsing and such, but that shouldn't be too much, and if hunspell-the-library can be fast enough, then I don't see why hunspell-the-CLI needs to be slow (there is probably something to win here).

> If you want to try out this PR (or wait until it reaches mainline), comparing the results for English/Dutch will be valuable.

`concencus` is `['consensus', 'con census', 'consents', 'concerns', 'concepts', 'consciences']` in Vim, and `['concurrences', 'concupiscence', 'concurrence', 'concussion']` with this PR ("consensus" what was intended, the Firefox suggestions are the same).

`Helo` is `['Hello', 'Halo', 'Hell', 'Hole', 'Hero', 'Held']` in Vim, and `['He lo', 'He-lo', 'Hole', 'Help', 'Helot', 'Hello']` with this patch. "Hello" is the "obvious" suggestion, but it's listed as fifth in hunspell (Firefox here is even more hopeless and doesn't list "Hello" at all).

There are some other pathological use cases with Hunspell; the "concencus" is something that I happened to encounter this week so I remembered it. I've heard some other people complain about it over the years too. I don't know if there are knobs to tweak in Hunspell or if anything can be improved, but Hunspell in Firefox has been a major PITA for me for years. Vim, but also just entering the word in DuckDuckGo or Google (entering "concencus" there also corrects it to the intended "consensus"), are better spell checkers for English than Hunspell.

**Edit 2022-09-30**: another one I got today: `dissapears`

    :echo spellsuggest(expand('<cword>'))[:5]
    Vim              ['disappears', 'disappear', 'disrepairs', 'diapers', 'dis spears', 'dissevers']
    Neovim/Hunspell  ['dispersal']

The only Firefox suggestion is `dissipaters`, which is different (maybe different Version? IIRC Firefox bundles it) but not very helpful.

> There is some added overhead from parsing and such, but that shouldn't be too much, and if hunspell-the-library can be fast enough, then I don't see why hunspell-the-CLI needs to be slow (there is probably something to win here).

The initial version of https://github.com/lewis6991/spellsitter.nvim in fact used the CLI version of hunspell and was very slow. This is because spellchecking is done whilst redrawing each line.  So for a roughly 80 line redraw the cost will be 80x5ms = 400ms, so half a second for every full screen redraw. I would guess most of this cost would be coming from the system call + the pipe IO.

Spellsitter did also cache the results. It helped, but not enough since you need to invalidate the cache on every `changetick`.

> The initial version of https://github.com/lewis6991/spellsitter.nvim in fact used the CLI version of hunspell and was very slow. This is because spellchecking is done whilst redrawing each line. So for a roughly 80 line redraw the cost will be 80x5ms = 400ms, so half a second for every full screen redraw. I would guess most of this cost would be coming from the system call + the pipe IO.

Why does it need to run on every redraw? And why does it need to send every line separately?

Either way, my main point was/is that Hunspell is not a drop-in "everything will be better" kind of replacement, and that while it may improve some use cases/languages, it also (IMHO seriously) regresses some other use cases.

I don't even use Neovim myself, I just ended up here "by accident" debugging an issue, so I'll leave it at that, but I'd be careful in just doing an outright s/vimspell/hunspell/g.

> Why does it need to run on every redraw?

That's just what it does now. If you don't do it when drawing lines, then you have to do it on file load for the whole buffer.

> And why does it need to send every line separately?

It doesn't need to, that's just what it does currently. This change only switches out the backend, it doesn't completely re-implement how spell checking is applied. The current implementation is quite naive/simple and re-implementing it to work around the bottlenecks of calling out to the system will be a huge amount of work, and not worth it considering these spellchecker backends are supposed to loaded as libraries anyway.

> Either way, my main point was/is that Hunspell is not a drop-in "everything will be better" kind of replacement, and that while it may improve some use cases/languages, it also (IMHO seriously) regresses some other use cases.

Your feedback is really valuable, and I think we need to rethink what to do here. Thank you.
Please don't forget `:spellrare` if this is going to be the path taken.

> Please don't forget `:spellrare` if this is going to be the path taken.

What does a rare word means exactly? Does hunspell support it (or any other spellchecker aside from vimspell)?

Is this still planned for v0.10?
It'd be amazing
I hope not, as still no `:spellrare` :joy:

Would it be too much to ask to rebase on the top of the current master, please? The base of this PR is getting so old that it breaks half of my configuration.

Also a bit of rearranging of commits [to make them more topical](https://who-t.blogspot.com/2009/12/on-commit-messages.html) would help. I am far from certain I understand whats going on here, but it seems to me that 31 is awfully a lot and some of these look like Lets try this  type of commits.

Otherwise, the current PR builds for me, but it doesnt seem to spell, but I am not sure whether it is because there is something wrong with the commits themselves, or that exactly it is too old and my configuration breaks somewhere.

For the record, I am not using this PR anymore.

The amount of work needed to switch to another spelling system made this option take too much time to maintain on my end.

Furthermore, I am not sure we _really want to_ make the switch, e.g. because of `spellrare` and other extremelly niche (yet used) features that vimspell has.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

labels.description: Nothing to see here; move along
labels.name: DO NOT MERGE

title: feat(spell): use hunspell as the spellchecking backend
